content: For the first 100 years of the electric power industry, electricity generation was centralized in large power plants. In response to the 1970s energy crisis, Congress promoted distributed generation, including customer-sited generation. One policy to encourage this is net metering, defined in the Energy Policy Act of 2005. Customer-sited generation, a form of distributed generation, can be located on various properties. Net metering, encouraged by Congress in the Energy Policy Act of 2005, allows electric energy generated on-site to offset energy provided by the utility. This report discusses current issues related to net metering policies, which determine how customers with distributed generation are compensated for electricity they provide to the grid. Net metering policies determine compensation for electricity delivered to the grid from distributed generation. Electricity generated is subtracted from consumption for billing, often referred to as "the meter running backward." A net metering customer is compensated on a one-to-one basis for electricity purchased from the grid, with every unit of electricity generated subtracted from their consumption for billing purposes. Different policy options include buy-all, sell-all, and net billing.
